column1: Ventricular Rate Control in Atrial Fibrillation
column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Digoxin may be alright for some individuals but for me it has been the "medicine from hell".  I seem to retain instead of eliminate digoxin from my system.  While I was taking the medication I had to constantly watch for signs of toxicity.  I was extremely fatigue, had headaches, mood swings and libido issues.  My cardiologist finally took me off digoxin and put me on another medication.  If digoxin works for you I would certainly use it but when it doesn't agree with one it can be a nightmare.

column9: I have been taking this medication for several years.  Just recently, I started having trouble with my eyes.  Everything white looked lavender. I received a call from the lab to go to the emergency room where I was told if I hadn't had a pacemaker/defibulator I would have been in real trouble.  Am now being monitored to get the level down.  If looking at a light and it appears to be yellow or green, that is a sign of toxicity.

column1: A Type of Fast Heartbeat - Paroxysmal Atrial Tachycardia
column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I began taking digoxin to treat SVT when the cause could not be identified by an EKG. When I told my doctor it was making my episodes occur more frequently, he increased the dose. I became nauseous,sweaty, had chest pain(which I NEVER had before taking digoxin), and another increase in the frequency of episodes that were now painful! I switched doctors and another EKG while on the digoxin revealed that I had WPW(digoxin is known to make WPW worse NOT better). I was taken immediately off the digoxin. If your medicine makes you feel worse tell your doctor and make sure they listen!
